Hello and welcome to this pre-recorded event
for GCE Statistics (S2) 6684.

9.text:
To help you get the most out of this feedback,
you may want to have the following documents

23.text:
handy as we will refer to them during the
session. Hard copies of the question paper

29.text:
and the mark scheme are essential to get the
full benefit from the feedback.

During the session we will take a look at
candidates' performance in each question and

50.text:
will consider common mistakes. You will have
the opportunity to allocate marks for some

53.text:
of the questions & to compare your mark with
the agreed mark. Let's make a start and look

67.text:
Overall this question was well done. In part
a the vast majority of candidates were able

75.text:
to gain full marks. However any errors that
arose were generally from writing the probability

83.text:
of 'Y' greater than or equal to 10 as 1 minus
the probability of 'Y' less than or equal

92.text:
to 10 or as 1 minus the probability of 'Y'
less than 9 or simply not looking up information

99.text:
correctly in the tables.
Part b was well completed. Most candidates

106.text:
were able to gain full marks here and most
used the Poisson formula as opposed to the

113.text:
tables. The most common mistakes were finding
the probability of 'Y' less than or equal

119.text:
to 2 rather than the probability of 'Y' equals
2 or using an incorrect value of lambda. A

129.text:
curious error was to approximate 1.8 by 2
to allow the question to be solved by the

135.text:
use of tables. This scored zero marks.
In part (c) most candidates realised the normal

144.text:
distribution was required and remembered that
the mean should equal the variance. Problems

151.text:
arose in applying the continuity correction,
with 470 and 470.5 being popular wrong routes,

162.text:
although 468 and 468.5 did make a number of
appearances. Overall a good proportion of

172.text:
candidates knew enough to use the correct
continuity correction and standardisation.

On the next slide there is a response to 1
part (c) to which you should allocate marks

using your copy of the mark scheme. When you

are ready press play to check your marking
against the agreed mark.

210.text:
As you can see from the slide, this response
achieves 4 out of the possible 6 marks. The

228.text:
student has realised that a normal approximation
is required with a mean & variance of 450

236.text:
& so gets the first two method marks.
They have also realised that a continuity

243.text:
correction is needed, but have standardised
using the incorrect value of 470.5. However

250.text:
they get a method mark for standardising using
an allowed value and another method mark for

259.text:
realising that a continuity correction is
needed. They then lose the accuracy marks

266.text:
as their answers for both the z-value and
the final probability are incorrect.

273.text:
How many marks would you give to the response
on the next slide?

279.text:
Again press pause, try marking the response
and then press play to check your marking

291.text:
on the next slide.
On this complete question 1 they score 6 out

309.text:
of 11.
In part a they have misread the tables.

315.text:
In part b they are completely correct.
In part c, although they know that the normal

323.text:
approximation to the Poisson is required and
they know the correct continuity correction,

329.text:
they have interpreted the second value in
the normal distribution notation to be the

335.text:
standard deviation resulting in an incorrect
z-value and hence incorrect answers. This

342.text:
one error has cost them 4 marks.
We will now move on to question 2.

352.text:
Part (a) proved challenging for many students.
Putting the expression - probability of 5

364.text:
being less than or equal to X which in turn
is less than 11, into an equivalent form that

372.text:
can be applied to the cumulative binomial
tables, that is - the probability of X less

379.text:
than or equal to 10 minus the probability
of X less than or equal to 4, led to many

387.text:
varied wrong expressions.
In part (b), although there were many students

392.text:
who got 3 or 4 marks for this part, there
were few getting full marks. As detailed in

400.text:
the slide there was usually a slip on some
aspect of conducting a hypothesis test. The

408.text:
most serious error was finding the probability
of X equal to 1 rather than the probability

415.text:
of X less than or equal to 1. The central
feature of a hypothesis test is to establish

424.text:
the probability of an event as bad or worse
than that observed under the conditions of

432.text:
the null hypothesis and, in this case, the
relevant event is X less than or equal to

440.text:
1.
On the next slide we see examples from two

445.text:
different responses to the mistakes described
above.

You may wish to press pause on this slide
in order to see how the marks have been awarded.

When ready to move onto question 3, press
play.

488.text:
In Question 3 part a, whilst most got full
marks using the standard method given in the

494.text:
mark scheme, a few candidates, some of whom
were successful, used an alternative method.

502.text:
Anticipating part (c) they found the cumulative
distribution function capital F of x in terms

509.text:
of 'k' and a constant C. A minority thought
this was a discrete distribution and tried

517.text:
to find sigma 'x' times the probability of
x.

521.text:
For part b, successful candidates generally
used a sketch. Those candidates who did not,

529.text:
tended to think the mode was 6.
In part c most got the cumulative distribution

537.text:
function for the first part of the function
between zero and 2 and also stated the function

543.text:
correctly for values less than zero and greater
than 6. For line 3, dealing with the function

551.text:
from 2 to 6, most candidates neither used
capital F of two equals 1 nor the alternative

560.text:
method given in the mark scheme. They merely
just integrated the second part of the probability

566.text:
density function & obtained an incorrect constant.
For part d most students put line 3 of the

576.text:
cumulative distribution function equal to
0.75 often obtaining a quadratic equation.

584.text:
However some added lines 2 and 3 of the cumulative
distribution function before equating to 0.75

593.text:
thus leading to a cubic equation. Very few
of the candidates getting a quadratic equation,

601.text:
either correct or incorrect, made any attempt
to solve it.

On the next slide there is an opportunity
to allocate marks to parts (c) and (d) of

Press pause on this slide and use the mark
scheme to allocate marks to parts (c) & (d)

of question 3. When you have finished press
play to compare your mark with the agreed

marks.
As you can see this response earns 3 marks

650.text:
out of a possible 9.
They have obtained the method and accuracy

658.text:
mark for the 2nd line of the cumulative distribution
function. However their attempt at the 3rd

664.text:
line using the second alternative did not
include limits 2 & x on their integral thus

672.text:
losing both method and accuracy marks. They
do earn the B mark for correct 1st and 4th

680.text:
lines. In the last part they do obtain a quadratic
equation which they attempt to solve, but

687.text:
it was obtained by equating their line 3 to
0.25 thus losing both method and accuracy

697.text:
marks as the second method mark is dependent
on having scored the initial method mark.

705.text: We will now move on to Question 4.

711.text:
In parts a to c most candidates scored full
marks. Parts b and c could be obtained directly

723.text:
from the formula book, although a few students
integrated in part c in contrast to using

729.text:
the formula.
Students who correctly identified part d as

735.text:
being a binomial situation with n = 30 and
probability of success as being either 0.2

746.text:
or 0.8 generally were successful although,
as in question 1, there were some who had

754.text:
problems in identifying the correct inequality
to use.

759.text:
In part f, there were many correct solutions.
The main error was to use the normal approximation

768.text:
to the binomial rather than the Poisson approximation.
In this situation, the normal approximation

776.text:
is not appropriate as the probability of success
from part e is 0.04 & the binomial approximation

786.text:
needs a success probability near to 0.5.
On the next slide we see a response to question

796.text: 4 which gains 11 out of the possible 12 marks.

803.text:
As you can see, parts a, b, c, e & f all get
full marks.

815.text:
In part d however they have stated that the
probability of X greater than 0.4 is 0.1 and

825.text:
then have stated that what they call L is
approximated by a binomial with n = 30 and

834.text:
p = 0.1. They get the B mark for this, although
if they had not made the initial statement

843.text:
of X greater than 0.4 being 0.1 in this part
and had just stated the binomial approximation

852.text:
with 30 and 0.1 then they would have lost
both the B mark and the M mark. They then

861.text:
correctly identify that, with this approximation,
they require the probability of X less than

867.text:
or equal to 3 so get the M mark. They lose
the accuracy mark as they get the wrong answer,

876.text:
in fact they looked up the value in the cumulative
binomial table for n = 10 and p = 0.1.

888.text: We will now move onto question 5.

897.text:
Part a was answered well and showed a good
understanding of a critical region. A few

904.text:
wrote their critical region as a probability
but only rarely was an interval given as between

910.text:
two values, or the critical values of zero
and 9 stated on their own. For the candidates

920.text:
who did not give a correct critical region,
it is worth noting that to get the first method

926.text:
mark a probability from a Poisson distribution
with a parameter of 4 needs to be written

933.text:
down as evidence of using such a distribution.
In part b there were many who did not state

941.text:
their hypotheses nor give their conclusion
in the context of the question. In particular

948.text:
the mark scheme required the word 'Liftsforall'
to be given in the conclusion.

955.text:
In d, although there were many good solutions,
it required candidates to keep a very clear

962.text:
head about what they were counting. The problem
was not one of subject knowledge, nor was

969.text:
it one of technical competence. The challenge
was in interpreting the question and devising

976.text:
a suitable strategy. Many started this part
well and gained the first 3 marks. However

984.text:
many then used the binomial distribution incorrectly
to obtain the two required probabilities.

992.text:
Some did not realise that two probabilities
were needed or misapplied the binomial formula.

In part a of this question most candidates

1069.text:
realised that the integral of k x to the power
n between the limits x = 0 and x = 1 was equal

1079.text:
to 1, although sometimes the limits appeared
later. Similarly in part b most realised that

1087.text:
they were integrating x k x to the power n
but errors due to misunderstanding the laws

1094.text:
of indices were quite common.
Part c was usually answered correctly by those

1101.text:
who had successfully answered parts a and
b.

1105.text:
In part d, a minority were still unable to
distinguish between the expectation of X squared

1113.text:
and the variance of X & whilst most correctly
used the variance of 3X equal to 9 times the

1121.text:
variance of X, a high, but significant minority
for S2, thought that the variance

1127.text:
of 3X was equal to 3 times the variance of
X.

On the next slide, you should pause the presentation
and allocate marks for this example of question

1158.text:
As you can see in this slide, the student
has obtained full marks for parts a & b. However

1176.text:
they have quoted an incorrect formula for
the expectation of X squared and have lost

1183.text:
both marks in part c.
In part d they have stated that the variance

1189.text:
of 3X is 9 times the variance of X gaining
the second M mark, and then have correctly

1198.text:
calculated the variance of X, ignoring their
incorrect answer in part b for the expectation

1205.text:
of X squared, getting the first M mark in
the scheme. Unfortunately they have substituted

1214.text:
the wrong value for the variance of X so losing
the final accuracy mark. Hence they end up

1222.text:
with a final mark of 8 out of 11 for this
question.

1228.text:
We will now move on to the last question on
the paper, question 7.

1235.text:
In question 7, it was pleasing to see many
completely correct solutions. However a small

1246.text:
number of candidates made no progress beyond
establishing the probabilities of each coin

1252.text:
separately.
For those candidates between the above groups,

1254.text:
it was often a case of errors due to omitting
significant details. For example the problem

1264.text:
seen most often was omitting the triple 10,
20, 50 from the cases with a median of 20.

1273.text:
Of those students who included this triple,
many multiplied it by a factor of 3 rather

1279.text:
than 6.
Whilst adopting an inefficient strategy did

1284.text:
not matter as such, it obviously takes up
more time. One group of candidates created

1290.text:
a huge list, effectively a table with 4 columns
consisting of the triple, the median, calculation

1299.text:
of the probability of this triple and finally
the result of this calculation. There were

1305.text:
often 27 lines in this table.
Other common errors included using a shorthand

1313.text:
of 1, 2 and 5 for the medians 10, 20 & 50
but forgetting to convert back at the end,

1321.text:
or finding the probability of a median of
10 only, by conventional means, then subtracting

1328.text:
this from 1 and dividing the resulting probability
by 2 to give the alleged probabilities for

1335.text:
medians of 20 and 50. Just because the probabilities
of X = 20 and X = 50 are equal does not then

1346.text:
mean the probabilities for the medians of
20 and 50 are also equal.

1352.text:
Finally, using the mark scheme, see if you
can mark the following response to question

1362.text:
Press pause on this slide and mark this response.

As you can see, this response gets 5 out of

1392.text:
They have written down the probabilities of
picking each denomination of coin and have

1399.text:
identified the possible medians. They have
then shown correct calculations for the probabilities

1407.text:
of medians of 10p and 50p and have obtained
correct answers for these. For the 20p they

1414.text:
have missed out the triple 10, 20, 50 thus
leading to an incorrect calculation and answer

1422.text:
for the probability of a median of 20p. Thus
only two out of the three final probabilities

1430.text:
are correct.
We will now take a look at some of the reasons

1435.text:
that successful candidates did well and why
some students were not so successful in the

1444.text:
This slide gives some of the reasons that
candidates were successful.

1454.text:
It always makes a positive impression on the
examiner when working is set out in a clear

1460.text:
and logical way.
This paper involves the use of several probability

1466.text:
distributions. Successful candidates invariably
made clear the distribution being used.

1474.text:
Many errors were generated by reading the
wrong value from statistical tables. Successful

1481.text:
candidates took great care to make sure they
were reading the correct values.

1487.text:
Statistics is very much related to the real
world & we expect students to relate their

1494.text:
answers, where appropriate, to the real world
situation in the question.

1501.text:
In this slide we see some of the possible
reasons for students being less successful

1511.text:
in this exam.
An untidy script with no clear method given

1517.text:
and where the examiner is searching round
for the answer, does not help the candidate.

1524.text:
Showing the method will usually pick up method
marks particularly when the final answer is

1529.text:
wrong.
In S2, hypothesis testing is an important

1535.text:
topic and a clear understanding of the meaning
of null & alternative hypotheses, critical

1543.text:
region, one & two tailed tests and significance
level is essential.

1549.text:
Many candidates lose marks unnecessarily by
misreading statistical tables. Although this

1558.text:
occasionally involves reading the wrong table,
more often it is a case of writing down an

1565.text:
adjacent probability to the one required.
Candidates should double check that they have

1571.text:
the correct row and column in the table.
In question 6 of this paper, many weaker candidates

1580.text:
showed that they were not confident with the
laws of indices, which is a topic in C1. This

1586.text:
was often combined with leaving expressions
such as 1 to the power (n + 1) & not simplifying

1594.text:
them to 1. Such mistakes are disappointing
at this level.

2015 S2 paper.
